summary: A letter from the law firm Smith Villazor LLP to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding a subpoena issued by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program. The letter informs the court that the firm represents the program's administrator, accepts service of the subpoena, and requests a briefing schedule to file a motion to quash.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the United States v. Maxwell case, to whom the letter is addressed regarding a subpoena and motion schedule.

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.context: Attorney from Smith Villazor LLP who signs the letter and represents the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program; he is authorized to accept service of a subpoena.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the case.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the case.

persons.name: Mark Stewart Cohen
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the case.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Listed as an attorney copied on the letter, likely involved in the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual against whom the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program was established to resolve claims of sexual abuse.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (United States v. Maxwell) whose defense team is seeking a subpoena for documents from the compensation program.

connections.description: Patrick J. Smith's firm represents the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.
Maxwell is a defendant in a case related to Epstein, and the compensation program resolves claims against both Epstein and related individuals.
Smith is formally communicating with Judge Nathan regarding legal procedures (subpoena, motion to quash) in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Letter to Judge Nathan Regarding Subpoena
events.description: Smith Villazor LLP informs Judge Nathan that they represent the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program administrator, accept service of a defense subpoena, and request a briefing schedule to file a motion to quash.

events.title: Government Motion to Quash Deadline
events.description: The government intends to file its motion to quash the subpoena by this date.

events.title: Program's Motion to Quash Deadline
events.description: The court orders that Patrick J. Smith may file a motion to quash the subpoena on behalf of the compensation program by this date.

events.title: Defense Response Deadline
events.description: The defense is ordered to respond to both the government's and the program's motions to quash by this date.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense sought a subpoena under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 17(c) for documents from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.
The law firm Smith Villazor LLP represents the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and accepted service of the subpoena on their behalf.
The program was established to confidentially resolve claims of sexual abuse against Jeffrey Epstein, his estate, and other related individuals and entities.
The court set a briefing schedule for motions to quash the subpoena, with the government and the program's administrator filing separate motions and the defense given time to respond.
The document indicates legal efforts by Maxwell's defense to obtain materials from a confidential victim compensation program during her criminal trial.
